Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: The refinery was operating under normal conditions when a naphta leak occured in the pipestill. A contractor discovered the leak, and the alarm was activated manually. The plant was evacuated. The area was "foamed" and watercurtains activated in order to avoid that ; flammable gas was drifting towards potential ignition sources (ovens). Main parts of the refinery process units were shut down. The leakage was stopped 23:30. Leakage rate is estimated to be approximately 10 liters pr minute. In total 4400 liters was released and collected by an open drainage system. No environmental consequences.
Causes - Other: The pipe had fallen out of the electronic inspection system in 2008, and this was not identified. In connection with equipment strategy changes some years later, it was not identified that this pipeline was missing in the system.

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description:
INTRODUCTIION

An incident occurred, as from 20/09/2020 on the cryogenic ethane storage tank, resulting in ethane releases to atmosphere from one of the two tank relief valves until 25/09/2020. Total quantity of ethane released is evaluated at approximately 40 t over a period of 5 days.
Liquid ethane is stored in a cryogenic tank (capacity 11 000 m3, operating temperature - 88°C, operating pressure 12 mbarg). Tank pressure is controlled through :

- Boil-Off Gas (BOG) compressor (reciprocating compressor, OEM Burchardt), compressing ethane off gases from vaporization to fuel gas or furnaces,
 ;
- Flare compressor (centrifugal compressor, OEM Sundyne), fall back for BOG compressor to flare,
 ;
- Ultimately 2 relief valves (set pressure 30 mbarg), located at the top of the tank (~30m height).
 ;


SEQUENCE OF EVENTS

Friday 18/09/2020

18h00 ;  ; Completion of maintenance works on BOG compressor (repair of valve / unloader assembly due to vibration / noise, used to regulate compressor flow rate). Compressor restarted.
 ;
21h30 ;  ; Trip of BOG compressor due to low suction pressure. Tank pressure control taken over by flare compressor.

Saturday 19/09/2020

00h20 ;  ; Second start-up of BOG compressor, after intervention of instrumentation. Stop by operators of BOG compressor at 01h35 due to low suction pressure.
 ;
Day  ;  ; Abnormal presence of oil found in BOG compressor suction line. Compressor blinded. Cleaning of BOG suction line strainer.

Sunday 20/09/2020

Day ;  ; Inspection of BOG compressor internals revealing abnormal presence of oil on process side of the compressor. Necessity to go further with compressor overhaul and inspection.
 ;
19h00 ;  ; Trip of flare compressor due to high vibration. Unsuccessful restart. Gradual increase of tank pressure, resulting in opening of one of the two tank relief valves.Heat input from ambient environment and minimum flow of liquid ethane feed pump caused repeated liftings at a frequency of 3 times an hour for an interval of 2 minutes / lift, with ethane release to atmosphere (~0.8 t/h). Tank pressure varying from 25 to 35 mbarg. Gas detection located at the top of the tank in alarm during relief valves opening. No alarms on gas detection at ground level (next to tank, located at BOG compressor ). Night shift by maintenance for dismantling of flare compressor.

Monday 21/09/2020

Day ;  ; Duty multi-disciplinary team put in place. Tank inventory @05h : 910 t.Definition of conservative safety perimeter (150 m) around tank (no works, no loadings), on basis of dispersion calculation (20 m 100% LEL). Safety perimeter remains inside establishment fences. Extra mobile gas detection put in place at ground level. Water curtains put in place around tank. Nitrogen flushing of relief valves outlet in service (reduction of ignition and freezing risks).Information of Headquarters and authorities.Ethane cracking restarted and maximized to empty tank. Closing of liquid ethane recirculation to tank to reduce frequency of relief valves lifting to once per hour. Disassembling / expertise of flare compressor. Damages found on impeller blade, casing, high speed shaft and bearing. Oil film found in compressor stator. Replacement of parts and repair works ongoing.Internal inspection (endoscopy) of flare compressor suction and discharge line : no oil detected.Disassembling / expertise of BOG compressor in parallel. ; ;


23h30 ;  ; Relief valve stuck in open position, causing tank pressure drop.Trip of ethane feed pump from F2103 to furnaces upon low suction pressure, causing strong disturbances on furnaces and risk of off spec products with potential flare activity.

Tuesday 22/09/2020

00h50 ;  ; Activation of internal emergency plan level I and II (highest priority). Mobilisation of internal emergency crisis cell. Definition of intervention strategy. Mobilisation of external emergency crisis cell, temporary closing of public road next to the establishment.
 ;
03h00 ;  ; Intervention at tank top, with assistance of public fire department. Throttling of block valve upstream stuck relief valve. Opening of 3 vents on level measurements at tank top. Tank pressure back under control (~12 mbarg). Ethane release to atmosphere estimated ~230 kg/h.
 ;
04h30 ;  ; End of internal emergency plan level II.
 ;
Day ;  ; Completion of flare compressor repair works.
 ;
17h00 ;  ; Unsuccessful start-up of flare compressor, trip on high vibration, two start-up attempts.

Wednesday 23/09/2020

Day ;  ; Dismantling / expertise of flare compressor, with onsite assistance of group experts. Damages found on high speed shaft and bearings, no damage on impeller. Not sufficient spare parts available, already used during first overhaul on 21/09/2020.Multi-disciplinary investigation team with group experts and local specialists to identify BOG failure root cause.Ethane cracking remained stopped (stability of operation furnaces, no heat input in tank by pump recirculation at low throughputs).

Thursday 24/09/2020

Day ;  ; Pursue of technical expertise of flare compressor, with experts.Reassembly of BOG compressor, no mechanical damages found. Inspection and oil cleaning of BOG process lines and drums. Review of start-up procedure (close valve nitrogen injection to crank shaft chamber prior to start-up to avoid oil carry over to process side = root cause of trip BOG compressor).

Friday 25/09/2020

10h30 ;  ; Completion of mechanical works. Restart of BOG compressor. Stop of ethane release to atmosphere. Authorities informed.
Causes of the accident:
BOG compressor :

The investigation with experts indicates as root cause an overpressure of nitrogen in compressor crank case during operation leading to (excessive) oil leakage through oil packings and oil ingress into gas packing vents. Gas packing vent is connected with compressor suction, which explains oil in suction lines.

Flare compressor :

The first failure of the flare compressor on 20/09/2020 (damaged impeller) is due to:

1) a not visible damaged impeller during overspeed testing at the manufacturer, inducing the start of crack forming in the impeller of the flare compressor
2) frequently operating in a certain speed range (rpm) in combination with a high process flow through the compressor inducing internal instability

The second failure on 22/09/2020 (damaged shaft and bearings) is due to:

1) Operating flare compressor with a (too) high process gas flow, caused by a (too) high temperature of the process gas (-14°c instead of -88°c). This high temperature was caused by a standstill of the inlet piping during 5 days, where process gas was heated up from the environment
2) A closed valve at the recirculation (kickback) gas flow back to the suction of the compressor
Lesson Learned: The starting procedure for the BOG compressor was not sufficiently clear which lead to errors while starting the compressor that caused the compressor to fail. ; This procedure has been updated to describe the staps more clearly. The BOG compressor has been modified to be more reliable.

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: A fire occured in the compressor house of the methanol plant. In this compressor house, in addition to containing equipment for compressing the synthesis gas (H2, CO2 and CO), there was also located a steam powered turbine generator with belonging equipment. When the fire started, the methanol plant was shut down. The attempted emergency stop of the steam powered turbine generator resulted in a total breakdown of the generator. Several components loosened from the turbine, were flung out with great force, and hit pipelines for the lube oil system inside the compressor house. This caused a lube oil leak, which ignited.The fire did not spread to the other systems in the compressor house. The incident had a major accident potential and could have caused serious personal injury or death as well as substantial economic loss.
Fire Major Occurences: not known / not applicable
Causes of the accident:
Direct cause: The direct cause of the turbine breakdown with subsequent fire was that isolation from the steam network at the intermediate pressure level failed to function as intended during emergency shut down of the system. This happened because a back flow valve did not function as intended. The back flow of steam increased the rotation in the turbine, which again caused that components loosened from the turbine and were flung out with great force.
Underlying causes are: The criticality of the valve was from the start of the plant wrongfully classified as low. This mistake had not been identified in later system reviews of the maintenance system. Due to this, only temporary repairs had been made on the valve that should prevent back flow of steam from the steam pipelines to the steam turbine, even though they had experienced problems with the valve for a long time. Nine corrective jobs had been performed on this valve during the last year, the latest work order on the valve's actuator had not been performed according to the deadline, and because the valve was not identified as safety critical this delay was not evaluated. ;
Theme of the Lessons Learned:
Causes - Plant/Equipment
Causes - Organisational
Emergency Response
Lesson Learned:
Insufficient identification of safety critical equipment and systematic follow up of technical integrity.
Insufficient barriers for reducing the possibility of dangerous situations.
Documentation for mechanical components was not easily available
Minimum safety distances for emergency personnel was not established
A performance standard for personnel check (POB) in the plant was not established. ;

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: During restart of a LNG production facility a fire occured in the air intake for one of 5 gas turbine generators. The fire caused material damage of the turbine air inlet and filterhouse, and the salty water used to extinguish the fire caused damages on electric and mechanical equipment. The LNG production facility has been closed since the accident occured, and was still not reopened by the end of 2021. ;
Fire Major Occurences: not known / not applicable
Theme of the Lessons Learned:
Causes - Plant/Equipment
Causes - Organisational
Emergency Response

Industry Type: Chemical installations - Industrial gases
Accident Description: At around 3:00 a.m., at an industrial and medical gas company, 15.2 ;tonnes of liquid oxygen spilled via an overflow valve on a 1,000 ;m³ storage tank into the tank’s bund. The duty technician noticed this when he arrived the next day. He cut off the supply to the storage tank and diverted the surplus liquid oxygen from the tank to the ejector. The accumulated liquid evaporated.
Release Major Occurrences:
gas/vapour/mist/etc release to air
fluid release to ground
Causes of the accident: At the start of the COVID-19 lockdown, stocks were maintained at an abnormally high level (no industrial oxygen was being withdrawn and provision had been made for potential increased demand for medical oxygen). The overflow valve is a risk-management measure aimed at preventing the tank from being overfilled and its dome opening. This physical overflow occurred without the tank’s very high level alarm going off. The tank’s high level alarm was not turned on and the very high level alarm had not been set properly: the value of the very high threshold was not adapted to the position of the overflow valve. The oxygen spilled into the bund without triggering the low temperature sensor fitted to it. The inspection carried out by the authorities following the accident found, among other things, that the filling limit of the tank had not been complied with.
Organizational Causative Factor Type:
management organization inadequate
design of plant/equipment/system
installation

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: At 5:13 a.m. on a Sunday, an alarm went off after volatile organic compounds were detected in a room inside the laboratory of a refinery (1.2 ;ppm of VOCs detected; alarm threshold of 1 ;ppm). A laboratory staff member called the site’s fire officers to report an odour. When they arrived, the fire officers found that the sensor was showing 5 ;ppm and they evacuated the two laboratory staff members. 60 ;ppm of VOCs and 0.6 ;ppm of benzene were detected outside the laboratory. Benzene at 20 ;ppm was detected in the vicinity of two gasoline storage tanks. The laboratory was aired and no more benzene was detected there. The ventilation systems of the nearby buildings were switched to using recycled air. An odour could be smelled again in the early afternoon. Water and benzene were found to be present on the floating roof of one of the storage tanks. There had been heavy rain over the weekend. The operator pumped 35 ;m³ of product into the collection pit of the roof’s drainage system and sprayed a carpet of foam into the pit. A strong odour could again be smelled the following day. Product was again found on the roof. The operator decided to close off some control rooms, to evacuate some facilities and to seal off the refinery. Around 80 ;m³ of a mixture of gasoline and stormwater was pumped. This mixture included 20 ;m³ of benzene.
Substance Classification:
P5b. FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS  cat. 2 or 3  creating hazard conditions (n. 12)
00. NAMED SUBSTANCE
Lesson Learned: The operator intends to improve the planning of works to prepare for maintenance. The roof support legs will not be retracted until shortly before the works so as not to allow an intermediary situation to persist for more than a few hours.

Industry Type: Plastic and rubber manufacture
Accident Description: A loss of containment of styrene monomer occurred in an outlet pipe from a storage tank in a polystyrene manufacturing plant.
Substance Classification: P5b. FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS  cat. 2 or 3  creating hazard conditions (n. 12)
Causes of the accident:
The leak occurred when a manual valve was being replaced on the extraction line from the tank.
As the tank is equipped with two valves in series on the extraction line, the automatic electrical valve on the bottom of the tank (downstream of the tank) was closed manually using the local mechanical switch in order to isolate the manual valve to be replaced from the tank. The maintenance staff then opened the flange located after the manual valve in order to replace it.
Closing the electrical valve manually triggered alarms in several areas of the plant. When the alarm was deactivated from one of these areas, the automatic valve opened again via the electric motor and the styrene flowed out through the manual valve to be replaced, which was in the open position.
The electrical valve was not electrically isolated either by the operator or by the external contractor responsible for the work. The safety instructions include the electrical lockout of equipment. Moreover, there is no procedure for deactivating alarms.

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: At a petrochemical site, gaseous hydrocarbons leaked from a 3-inch pipe under pressure of 300 mbar.
Causes of the accident:
The incident occurred during a prolonged cold spell, when the temperature had remained below freezing for 8 days and had fallen as low as -18 °C. The equipment was designed for a minimum temperature of -12 °C. The damaged section developed a crack of 5-6 cm caused by the pipe freezing and began to leak with the thaw. The accumulation of water in the piping resulted from the presence of wet gas and the fact that no product flowed through the unused branch. An inspection 8 years previously had not detected any significant loss of metal thickness in this section, which was classified at a low criticality level.
The leak took a long time to locate because the gas is colourless and because of the site and height of the section, the non-activation of the gas detectors in the unit and insufficient information from the operative in the control room. The operative manages stocks of diluent per item of equipment and per hour, but does not have any summary view of the overall daily consumption of diluent across the entire unit. This figure can only be obtained by means of a detailed analysis, which pinpoints the start of the leak to more than 3 days before the accident. The day before, abnormal consumption of diluent had been detected on the display screen, but the low pressure in the section, the height of the piping and the colourless nature of the product meant that the leak could not be located precisely. An operative found it by chance the following day when climbing scaffolding erected for planned maintenance.
Organizational Causative Factor Type:
supervision
process analysis
isolation of equipment/system
testing/inspecting/recording
Theme of the Lessons Learned:
Causes - Plant/Equipment
Causes - Organisational
Causes - External
Lesson Learned: The damaged piping was removed a few weeks later and the operator took a number of measures to remove or monitor the presence of water in pipes with the same characteristics and carrying toxic or flammable fluids in times of extreme cold: sections concerned put out of service, removal of water from the pipes or enhanced vigilance in the event of meteorological hazards.

Industry Type: Chemical installations - other fine chemicals
Accident Description: The accident occurred around 10:15/10:30 (it was raining at the time the event occurred), when a fire broke out in the area of tanks TK 2.1 and TK 2.2 at a plant producing light stabilisers for the cosmetics market, which was in operation at the time of the event. The accident occurred during modification works, carried out by an external firm (mechanical and electrical/instrumentation maintenance assistance), which was connecting tank TK 2.2 to the waste water network. For this work, a regular work permit and a hot work licence were issued, the latter having been issued following preliminary checks for the safe preparation of the area, in accordance with the applicable safety management system (SMS) procedure. By 9:30, the external workers had cut the pipe that was being worked on using an angle grinder and were preparing to place the new pipe, as planned, after having constructed the fitting where the pipe was to be attached. The event occurred when the previously cut pipe was being sealed, while an electric arc welder was in use. The external workers involved (two operators, with appropriate PPE) were on a work platform set up to ensure the safety of the activities in question, approximately 8-10 m above ground level. This work platform was approximately 5 m from the outer perimeter of tank TK 2.2. The way the event developed resulted in an internal domino (cascade) effect which affected all plants at the establishment.
Fire Major Occurences:
conflagration (a general engulfment fire)
flash fire (burning vapour cloud, subsonic flame front)
Fire Initiating Events:
conflagration (a general engulfment fire)
flash fire (burning vapour cloud, subsonic flame front)
Substance Classification:
P5c. FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS cat. 2 or 3 not covered by P5a and P5b
E2. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Chronic 2
Causes of the accident: The accident occurred as a result of modification works that were being carried out by a third company, which was modifying a connection between the wastewater network and tank TK 2.2. The use of an electric arc welder when sealing the previously cut pipe caused the flammable mixture within the tank (waste water vapour) to ignite. Furthermore, according to statements from the plant operators, the tank on which the line modification work was to be carried out (TK 2.2) was blanketed with nitrogen pumped in through the same pipe that was cut and then welded, at approx. 2.5 bar. It is possible that, precisely as a result of cutting the pipe, the inert nitrogen atmosphere was lost due to the broken connection.
Organizational Causative Factor Type:
management organization inadequate
management attitude problem
organized procedures
training/instruction
supervision
process analysis
design of plant/equipment/system
isolation of equipment/system
maintenance/repair
Causes - Other:
1. Design of plant/equipment/system: presence of hazardous substances stored on the forecourt which were not adequately protected by fire prevention systems. 
2. Process analysis: there is no evidence of risk analyses having been done on the modification
Lesson Learned:
Always conduct a risk analysis on all types of modifications in accordance with the appropriate SMS procedure for management of changes (preliminary risks, risks during implementation and risks during operation), resulting in the identification of preventive and protective measures to be implemented, as well as the related training activities for the staff involved.
Always keep systems subject to modification works under isolated and inert conditions to prevent the environmental conditions from changing, which could lead to the formation of potentially flammable and/or explosive atmospheres.
The work permit process must always pay attention to: checks prior to and/or during the performance of the activities, supervision by the persons responsible and formalisation.
Follow the procedures for the correct positioning of stores of hazardous substances and mixtures on the forecourt (e.g. tanks, drums, IBCs, etc.), including related fire protection systems and equipment, as a result of an appropriate risk analysis.
During inspections by the competent authorities, pay attention to the link between risk analysis and management of changes, including those of a temporary nature, in the fine chemicals sector (batch reactions).
Carry out continuous analysis of the operational experience gained from accidents, near misses and anomalies through the specific SMS procedures, and record in the relevant documentation the causes identified, the substances involved, how the incident happened, how the emergency was managed and the corrective actions implemented, instead of simply describing the events.

Industry Type: Production of pharmaceuticals
Accident Description: At around 9:30, an ammonia leak occurred via a purge valve on a supply pipe to an NH3 storage sphere at a chemical plant.
Substance Classification:
H2. ACUTE TOXIC  cat. 2 or 3 (n. 7)
P2. FLAMMABLE GASES cat. 1 or 2
E1. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Acute 1 or Chronic 1
00. NAMED SUBSTANCE
Causes of the accident: The purge valve through which the leak occurred is between two sectional valves on the pipe supplying the NH3 sphere. In preparation for the planned checks, the sphere had been emptied and isolated from its NH3 supply. In order to do this, the two sectional valves were locked shut and the purge valve was locked open. The leak occurred during a transfer of NH3 from the unloading station directly to production. It was caused by a failure of the seal on the first sectional valve.
Lesson Learned: Check the seal on valves after each shutdown period.

Industry Type: Processing of ferrous metals (foundries, smelting, etc.)
Accident Description: Two explosions occurred in a vacuum arc remelting furnace containing five ;tonnes of titanium at a metallurgy plant.
Explosion Major Occurences: rapid phase-transition explosion (rapid change of state)
Causes of the accident: Analysis of the accident shows that the first explosion was linked to the generation of an electric arc on the furnace’s stinger. This arcing for 29 seconds pierced the stinger cooling water circuit. The water poured into the furnace and evaporated on contact with the metal, producing hydrogen. The pressure in the furnace rose. The steam and hydrogen were evacuated through the valve from the furnace’s air pumping circuit, but the pressure continued to rise. The portholes of the furnace give way in turn. When the water circuit was shut off by the foundry worker, the pressure decreased and air entered the furnace. The mixture of hydrogen and air became explosive, resulting in the first explosion and the destruction of the furnace casing and crucible cooling circuit. The crucible cooling water poured onto the molten metal on the ground, generating steam and hydrogen. Mixed with air, the hydrogen caused the second, more violent explosion. The secondary arcing could have been the result of a problem of geometry, surface condition and/or quality of the fitting of the parts (stinger, stub and tip). The stinger secondary arcing scenario was not considered in the hazard assessment.

Industry Type: Production of basic organic chemicals
Accident Description: A butadiene sphere at a chemical plant was being filled with water when one of its valves opened, releasing a mixture of water and butadiene. The mixture was collected in the containment basin. The amount of butadiene released into the atmosphere is estimated at 8 t (calculated using mass balance).
Release Major Occurrences:
gas/vapour/mist/etc release to air
fluid release to ground
Causes of the accident:
The 1,500 t sphere (which still contained 100 t of butadiene) was being emptied in preparation for a major turnaround of the manufacturing unit for maintenance and inspections. The operation involved filling the sphere to the top with water to transfer the residual butadiene by overflow to a second sphere. The supply rate of the sphere was increased during the operation by installing a DN 100 diameter, 10 bar supply pipe, without assessing the associated risks. The resulting flow rate was too high compared to the overflow rate to the second sphere. The pressure in the first sphere therefore increased until the valve opened. There are no concerns about the calibration of the valve.
The incident was the result of a change in the list of points to be checked (change of supply rate) for an emptying operation, with an insufficient assessment of the risks associated with that change.

Industry Type: Processing of ferrous metals (foundries, smelting, etc.)
Accident Description: At around 16:30 at a steel plant, a loss of containment occurred followed by an explosion in one of the site’s four boilers.
Explosion Major Occurences: VCE (vapour cloud explosion; supersonic wave front)
Substance Classification:
H2. ACUTE TOXIC  cat. 2 or 3 (n. 7)
P2. FLAMMABLE GASES cat. 1 or 2
E1. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Acute 1 or Chronic 1
Causes of the accident: The loss of containment was due to the emergency shutdown of the boiler following a loss of power to the transformer. This loss of power also generated a massive and sudden inflow of seawater into the condensers (cooled by seawater). This resulted in a massive addition of chlorine and oxygen to the circuit and accelerated the corrosion of the tubes already weakened by poor water quality.
External Causes: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)
Lesson Learned:
Control of the chemical quality of the boiler feed water (chloride content).
Study on the design of the attachment of the burner belts and casing in order to avoid the phenomenon of fatigue cracking on the elbow tubes and burner casing support tubes.
Study on the choice of materials for boiler tubes with regard to the phenomenon of cracking caused by high-temperature hydrogen attack.

Industry Type: Chemical installations
Accident Description: On the night of the accident, the production team had to pack 5 l containers of bleach. Once the stock in the buffer tank was exhausted, an operative activated the transfer pump and opened the check valve of the corresponding tank. A hydraulic shock occurred as a result of the vacuum caused by the pump starting before the valve had been opened. A bend downstream of the valve detached from its PVC piping. The tank partially supplied the production line, but emptied partially into the bund via the detached bend until the accident was discovered by the patrol 2 hours later.
Substance Classification: E1. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Acute 1 or Chronic 1
Causes of the accident:
Four months previously, the operator had abolished the night team specifically responsible for transferring products between the storage tanks and the packing lines.
Once the stock had been exhausted in the buffer tank, one of the operatives had to go to the building housing the storage depot control station at around 22:00. From the control desk, he started the transfer pump then opened the check valve on the corresponding tank. A hydraulic shock occurred as a result of the vacuum caused by the pump starting before the valve had been opened. A bend downstream of the valve detached from its PVC piping. The tank partially supplied the production line, but emptied partially into the bund via the detached bend until the accident was discovered by the patrol 2 hours later. The bund sensor malfunctioned and did not trigger a visual alarm at the site guard house. The investigation has revealed that there were no operating instructions or instructions for transfer operations, despite the production team not being trained in the use of the transfer control station (a task previously carried out by a specialised team). Once the transfer was launched, no one remained in the building housing the control station to monitor the smooth operation of the transfer remotely. The control station display did not show the position of the valve at the base of the tank, which could have alerted the operative to the risk of water hammer in the transfer pipes. The working of the transfer pump was not linked to the correct opening of the tank check valves nor to the detection of low levels in tanks. Once the leak was detected, staff did not activate the balloon plug for the site’s sewerage systems, contrary to the instructions in place.
Organizational Causative Factor Type:
management organization inadequate
organized procedures
training/instruction
supervision
maintenance/repair
testing/inspecting/recording
Lesson Learned:
Importance of having staff trained in action to be taken and safety and emergency procedures.
Drawing up of clear instructions.
Maintenance of sensors for safety management.

Industry Type: Production of pharmaceuticals
Accident Description: Groundwater contamination by N-nitrosomorpholine (nitrosamine family) was discovered during a research survey of undesirable substances in water intended for human consumption. The substance, which is potentially carcinogenic, originated from the treatment plant at a pharmaceutical plant. It was not one of the products to be analysed under the regulations in force.
Causes of the accident: Reaction of morpholine with nitrites within the treatment plant, leading to the formation of N-nitrosomorpholine (potentially carcinogenic).
Lesson Learned: Ban on nitrosamine in production. This was not one of the products to be analysed under the regulations in force.

Industry Type: Processing of metals
Accident Description:
At 16:15 an explosion occurred followed by a fire in a 370 m³ detarrer in the gas treatment area at a coking plant. The extractors were activated manually. The operator activated the internal emergency plan at 16:25. The staff were evacuated. A security perimeter was established. The fuel supply to the installation was shut off. The heating of the batteries was stopped. At 20:00 the fire was extinguished by inerting with nitrogen. The weakened structure was at risk of collapse. At 20:30 the upstream and downstream valves on the detarrer and H2S scrubber were closed, coke oven gas was restored, nitrogen was injected into the gas collector and the structure was assessed. The operator installed solid joints on flanges to isolate the detarrers and the H2S scrubber.
According to the operator, no hazardous or polluting material was released into the atmosphere apart from the (limited) smoke from the fire. The operator estimates the maximum amount of material that reacted in the explosion of the detarrer at 170 kg TNT equivalent. Crude coke gas from coal distillation was burnt in the bleeders (flares above oven batteries) for almost 5 days, which was the time it took to return to service the gas treatment (the detarrer that was destroyed and the H2S scrubber were isolated from the coke gas treatment system and remained out of service for several months). The estimated volume of coke oven gas sent to the bleeders is 3,776,600 Nm³.
Coke gas was then flared for 90 days until the detarrer was replaced.
In total, the operator estimates that 36,790 t of coke oven gas was released and burned via the bleeders and then the flares. A health impact assessment was carried out and the SO2 emissions were modelled – according to the operator this is the only pollutant from combustion that could affect the public. The operator concludes that neither the daily average limit value for the protection of human health, the information and recommendation threshold nor the alert threshold were exceeded.
Following the incident, the damage to outlet valves and pipes was analysed. The work to rebuild the detarrer lasted several months. The material losses are estimated at EUR 10 million and production losses at EUR 9 million.
A 25 mm hole and a crack had been detected on the steam circuit 8 months before the accident which could not be repaired without stopping the detarrer. As monitoring of the oxygen level at the detarrer outlet did not show any anomalies, the repair was scheduled for the routine shutdown 3 days after the day of the accident.
There are several hypotheses as to the origin of the ignition energy: electrostatic due to friction of the air/gas mixture (also comprising dust) on metal plates, chemical due to the presence of pyrophoric material, or mechanical due to a piece of metal falling inside the detarrer. The external expert assessment concluded that the most likely hypothesis was contact between the coke oven gas and oxygen from the air coming from the leak in the steam network and ignition by electrostatic energy generated by friction between the gases and the metal walls.
An electrostatic detarrer had already exploded at this site in July 2005 and at other sites of the group abroad in November 2017 and in 2019. The explosions always occurred when the detarrer was put back into service by supplying the electric fields but never during washing and draining, when the electric fields are not supplied (no ignition source). There were therefore no lessons learned and the risk had not been identified by the operator.
Following this accident, the operator reviewed the risk analyses and undertook additional measures, including revising the procedure for washing the detarrer by carrying out the washing and draining operations under pressure in order to avoid any air entry.
Fire Major Occurences: conflagration (a general engulfment fire)
Explosion Major Occurences:
dust explosion
explosive decomposition (of unstable material)
Explosion Initiating Events:
dust explosion
explosive decomposition (of unstable material)
Substance Classification:
H2. ACUTE TOXIC  cat. 2 or 3 (n. 7)
P2. FLAMMABLE GASES cat. 1 or 2
E1. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Acute 1 or Chronic 1
Causes of the accident:
The electric fields of the detarrer were switched off because it was in the washing and draining phase. There was no obvious source of ignition for the gas.
There are various hypotheses:

Electrostatic energy was created by friction between the unpurified air/gas mixture that still contained dust and the metal plates, creating a source of ignition.
Pyrophoric materials potentially present could have caused the explosion on contact with oxygen.
A piece of metal potentially falling inside the detarrer could have created a spark.

The expert assessments carried out did not reach a clear conclusion as to the source of the ignition.
Plant/Equipment Causative Factor Type:
loss of process control
unexpected reaction/phase-transition
electrostatic accumulation
Lesson Learned: Revision of the procedure for washing the detarrer by carrying out the washing and draining operations under pressure in order to avoid any air entry.

Industry Type: Production and storage of fertilizers
Accident Description: 113 tons of nitric acid leaked out from a tank and into the sewer/ ground. Two months earlier a valve was changed as preventive maintenance, and, a valve with material quality that was not compatible with nitric acid was installed. This resulted in corrosion in the tank, and the following release.
Release Major Occurrences:
fluid release to ground
fluid release to water
Release Initiating Event:
fluid release to ground
fluid release to water
Causes - Other: Insufficient barriers did not ensure installation of parts with correct quality.
Lesson Learned:
Installation: Old installation was missing shut off valve inside bundwall. ; An upgrade of the two acid storage tanks with shut of valves inside the bundwall is necessary.
Organisation: Lack of proper control routines to safeguard correct quality of spareparts. New procedures are beeing developed to safeguard correct quality of spareparts beeing installed.

Industry Type: Production and storage of fertilizers
Accident Description: A pressurized ammonia sphere tank was taken out of operation for change of a level transmitter. The inlet valve for liquid ammonia to the sphere was closed, but ammonia was still passing through. High level alarms (High and High-High) came in, but the operators believed that the alarms were false since the sphere was closed out. This resulted in the sphere filling up completely and subsequently, liquid ammonia entered the ammonia gas system. This caused 4 episodes of ammonia releases during the period 10.07.2020 17:30 to 11.07.2020 09:30. 2 of these releases ocured relatively close to areas where people and vehicles may be present.
Causes of the accident:
Direct causes: The valve that was used to close the ammonia feed to the sphere was passing ammonia in spite of being in a closed position, and several alarms on high level where not reacted to because the operator believed the alarms to be false.
Contributing factors:

- Lack of understanding of the instrumentation system – that the level alarms where independent from the level indication.
- Insufficient communication
-Insufficient labeling of passing valves
-Missing risk assessment for the method used to close out the ammonia sphere ;
Causes - Other: Missing risk assessment for the method used to close out the ammonia sphere.
Theme of the Lessons Learned:
Causes - Plant/Equipment
Causes - Human
Causes - Organisational

Industry Type: Processing of ferrous metals (foundries, smelting, etc.)
Accident Description:
Workplace accident resulting in death during cleaning activities (scrubber, blast furnace) as a result of undetected inflow of blast furnace gas and unauthorised entry into the scrubber.
Safety measure:Immediate test of the safety systems.Halting of the cleaning activities.Systematic inspection of the plant conditions.Extensive investigations, including relating to cross-influences, followed by an on-site simulation.Investigation of possible hazards in the case of undefined valve positions in blast furnace hydraulics.Stricter controls and instructions for constant wearing of personal protective equipment, in particular gas detectors and emergency escape breathing devices.
Substance Classification:
P2. FLAMMABLE GASES cat. 1 or 2
No substances
Causes of the accident:
Unauthorised entry into the scrubber.Undetected sudden inflow of blast furnace gas into the scrubber, due to cross-influencing by other electrical switching work carried out simultaneously.The flow of blast furnace gas was possible because of a non-return valve that, for design reasons, did not close tightly after the blast furnace hydraulics operating pump was turned off and the stand-by pump did not start up.
In addition to human error, operational causes played a part.
Human: wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties
Lesson Learned:
Operation on principle of two blind valves during gas work as an additional safety measure.Updating the operational and organisational instructions with subsequent training, including for employees of contractors (job induction).Stricter controls for constant wearing of personal protective equipment, in particular gas detectors and emergency escape breathing devices.
Accident assessment will be incorporated into the update of the safety management system and the safety report, with the involvement of an expert pursuant to Section 29 of the German Federal Immission Control Act (Bundes-Immissionsschutzgesetz, BlmSchG).

Industry Type: Chemical installations
Accident Description:
The pressure monitor directly connected to the HF3 daily-supply tank detected increased pressure for four seconds and sounded an alarm as a result.When the alarm goes off, the circulation line’s feed valve to the HF3 daily-supply tank closes automatically.The plant employees concluded that this brief peak in pressure was an incorrect measurement and consequently paid no further attention to it. The employees did not notice that the feed line had closed. In the process control system, the valve closing is displayed both as an alarm activation and in the associated PID.
Because the drainage pump attached to the daily-supply pump continued to operate, it drained liquid HF out of the HF3 daily-supply tank via the pipeline that was open for purposes of outgassing, in the opposite direction to the usual direction of flow, and into the HF2 production plant.Then, during the ‘condensation’ process step, two holding tanks (V1 and V2) in the HF2 production plant were filled with liquid HF from the HF3 daily-supply tank. Before the two holding tanks were unintentionally filled, they were filled to a level of 24% (equivalent to 800 kg of HF 100).Very soon, the level indication there warned that the maximum permitted fill level had been reached (100%, equivalent to 3,400 kg).
At first the plant employees suspected that there had been internal corrosion damage in the cooling system, as a result of which large amounts of cooling brine had ended up in the interior of the condensation tank. The exothermic reaction expected in such a situation did not happen, which puzzled the employees.
Then the employees took additional measures to lower the critical fill level. In addition, they tried unsuccessfully to start one of the condensation tank’s priming pumps. A second priming pump had already been removed for repair.After this, all inflows into the condensation process step were closed. After a short time, liquid HF overflowed from an inspection opening on top of the V2 holding tank.
At an outside temperature of approximately 32 °C, the liquid FH (boiling temperature 19 °C) rapidly transitions to the gas phase and quickly becomes visible as a white vapour.
Safety measures:On-site fire service alerted.Once the fire service arrived, it contained the HF emissions by using mobile and fixed water monitors.Approximately 60 kg of HF 100, heavily diluted with water, was released into the acid drain in a controlled manner via the emergency drain in the ‘condensation holding’ floor area.The employees in the plant’s own waste water treatment facility were informed of this.The automatic changeover from waste water to containment was overseen by employees and occurred without problems.No contaminated water was released into the River Neckar.
Causes of the accident:
The plants were not in normal operation.
Human:

The employees categorised the activity as ‘non-dangerous’.
There was no structured risk assessment setting out special safeguards. Therefore no inspections of pipelines and instrumentation diagrams were carried out or documented.
Inadequate alarm management. The HH alarm and its line of action to the feed valve were not traced.
Insufficient observation. Neither the activated alarm nor the visual display of the feed valve closing were observed.
The connection between circulation mode and overfill of the holding tank was not recognised.

Technical:

The screw joint on the holding tank (discharge point) is unsuitable.
The pump for lowering the holding tanks’ critical fill levels is stuck.
The tank pressure measurement sends an erroneous signal (brief peak in pressure).
Lesson Learned:
Revise the risk analysis for the area of the HF plants.
Replace the HF inspection nozzle in conformity with the pipe class for hydrogen fluoride.
Adapt the maintenance strategy concerning feed pump replacement.
Install an additional monitor in the control room to improve alarm management.
Implement a training module for standard alarm management.
Train employees in alarm management.
Document activation measures in PIDs in the case of non-routine operating conditions.

It must be pointed out that, because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the HF plants were under temporary conditions. The HF2 production line was undergoing degasification in preparation for maintenance work; the HF3 production line was in circulation mode in order to prevent the pumps from becoming stuck.According to information from the operator, under normal operations these situations would not occur simultaneously. Because the possibility of mutual interference had not been investigated, the sequence of events resulting in this emission could not have been recognised in advance.
In connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, the European Commission’s Major Accident Hazards Bureau (MAHB) has developed a ‘Lessons Learnt Bulletin’:https://minerva.jrc.ec.europa.eu/en/shorturl/minerva/llb_covidv3pdf
In addition, the International Council of Chemical Associations (ICCA) has published a document addressing plant and process safety in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, with the title ‘Be Smart: Safe Restart – Re-Starting Chemical Production Facilities Post COVID-19 Restrictions’:https://www.americanchemistry.com/Be-Smart-Safe-Restart.pdf

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description:
On 23 August 2020, as a result of an operating error during an inspection of a faulty air compressor monitor at the catalytic cracking (FCC) plant, the FCC plant had a brief outage.On restarting the FCC plant on 24 August 2020, strong acid water containing hydrocarbons was introduced into the deodoriser via the plant’s cracked petroleum collector. The resulting stable emulsion was no longer separated out in the deodoriser’s inflow reservoir.Consequently, hydrocarbons flowed into the deodoriser.In the FCC area of the plant, the employees present judged the inflow of hydrocarbons into the deodoriser as tolerable, as they believed that the acid water from the plant’s cracked petroleum collector would be immediately separated into a different tank and therefore would be harmless to the deodoriser.However, the separation into a different tank takes place after the deodoriser’s inflow reservoir. The employees in the FCC area of the plant were unaware of this.
Under normal operations, acid water is cleaned in the deodoriser first via an H2S stripper and then via an ammonia (NH3) stripper.The stripped components from the H2S stripper, together with the H2S from the gas processing plant’s amine regenerators, are sent to the Claus plant via the diethanolamine gas separator; the stripped components from the NH3 stripper are sent to the Claus plant via the deodoriser gas separator.Because of the inflow of hydrocarbons into the deodoriser, both the H2S and the NH2 rich gases contained hydrocarbons, which were introduced into the Claus plant.
The introduction of hydrocarbons into the Claus plant triggered several effects. First of all, the Claus plant’s air consumption regulators began to run irregularly and the temperature in the downstream afterburner oven (KTI furnace) increased to the point of alerting the KTI furnace’s high-temperature switch-off (PCT protective device). In the context of the PCT protective device being alerted, the Claus plant’s tail gas was diverted around the KTI furnace via a bypass directly to the chimney. As a follow-up measure, the flow of NH3 rich gas was additionally sent to the H2S flare and burned there in order to stabilise the Claus plant and prevent a complete failure. In total, the Claus plant’s KTI furnace was out of service for a period of 9.5 hours.
The H2S emitted through the chimney during this period led to neighbourhood enquiries from various locations to the north and north-east of the refinery, at distances of between approximately 5 and 20 km.
Safety measures:Alerting the PCT protective device (here: high-temperature switch-off), so that the Claus plant’s tail gas was diverted via a bypass around the KTI furnace directly to the chimney.In order to stabilise the Claus plant and prevent a complete failure, the NH3 rich gas from the deodoriser was sent to the H2S flare system and burned via the flare stack of the elevated flare. The Claus plant was never completely out of service at any point. Reducing or shutting down other upstream refinery plants is too slow to be able to efficiently prevent potential further escalation in a short time.
Causes of the accident:
The FCC plant’s air compressor is monitored by various means, including a rotation speed shut-off. On 23 August 2020, one of the three rotation speed monitors broke down and was intended to be repaired that same day. For this, it is necessary to unlock the heavy oil component (HCO) and the catalytic cracked petroleum and gas oil component (LCO) shut-off channels of the rotation speed monitors.The HCO channels were unlocked while the LCO channels were overlooked.The failure to unlock these LCO channels caused the later outage of the FCC plant.
Prior to the start of the repair, the associated documents were examined. The associated operating diagrams concern plans for old AutoCAD (ACAD) applications which were drawn up after the air compressor was put into operation. Unlike what is common nowadays, in earlier times three sheets were used to depict these complex measuring circuits. In addition, the associated access switches are not depicted in the operating diagrams.The access switches can only be inferred from the circuit diagrams of the locking cabinet.A clear and simple depiction of the air compressor’s locks and associated access switches can be found in the associated functional matrix. However, this was not used as a source of knowledge during preparations for repairs.The air compressor’s locks are currently implemented in a wire-programmable control system. As compared to a memory-programmable control system, which is used nowadays to implement such locks, a clear overview of the locks is not shown in a wire-programmable control system.In a memory-programmable control system, the existing switch-offs per signal are clearly and unambiguously depicted.Therefore, it is less likely to overlook switch-off signals and access switches in a memory-programmable control system than in a wire-programmable control system. A detailed inspection of the program logic did not take place. Even in the case of this error pattern, this inspection would not have been necessary if the functional matrices had been used instead.On the basis of previous operational experience, an odour nuisance coming from the chimney during a bypass operation of the KTI furnace had never been observed in the past.On the day of the incident, the employees were acting on false assumptions with regard to the diversion of FCC acid water to the tank prior to the deodoriser. Essentially, the risk of significant consequences resulting from the addition of hydrocarbons to the deodoriser after a brief outage of the FCC plant was underestimated.The deodoriser inflow reservoir is neither designed nor suitable for separating the hydrocarbon phase from the water phase in the case of excessive inflow of hydrocarbons, especially when stable emulsions are introduced into the deodoriser inflow reservoir. Separation is only possible during significantly longer retention times.
In addition to the human errors described above, there were also process-related/technical causes (as described).
Lesson Learned:
Depicting and describing the concrete switch-off signals (jumper switches) on the printed form, as well as raising employee awareness of the topic of bypasses.This particularly means that when unlocking switch-off signals, the entire functionality must be carefully reviewed using the existing documentation (operating diagrams, circuit diagrams and, if available, the functional matrix), and all necessary functions must be unlocked.Updating the old ACAD operating diagrams for complex locks (those with more than two switch-off functions, with multiple thresholds resulting in various jumper switches) to have a more modern format and depicting the associated access switches in the operating diagrams.Drawing up a special operating plan as the standard operating plan for each FCC start-up. It will contain how to minimise acid water levels when starting the FCC plant and deodoriser during combination stripper operations. This operating plan will make it possible to separate the stripper waste gas during hydrocarbon inflow and burn it via the H2S flare. This will avoid negative effects on the Claus plant.
The incident clearly shows that overlooking a small measure during maintenance inspections can have significant effects and delayed reactions.The release of hydrogen sulphide did not result in any risk to the public.

Industry Type: Petrochemical / Oil Refineries
Accident Description: During a scheduled shutdown of a unit, an undue opening of a non operational line was made. As a result, a hydrogen sulphide realease occurred affecting two workers from a contractor company.
Substance Classification:
H2. ACUTE TOXIC  cat. 2 or 3 (n. 7)
P2. FLAMMABLE GASES cat. 1 or 2
E1. Hazardous to the Aquatic Environment cat. Acute 1 or Chronic 1
Causes of the accident: Unauthorised opening of a non operatotional line (6" diameter) by workers from a contractor company
Lesson Learned:
Reinforce training on work permits rules and protocols to follow during plant shutdown
Reinforce training on the use of sulphide personal detectors

Industry Type: Manufacture of food products and beverages
Accident Description: Ignition of vegetal sediments with hexane residues in the extractor evaporator. Burning of the evaporator thermal insulation, explosion of the hexane/air mixture in the condenser. Finally, the hexane extractor exploded. ;
Fire Major Occurences: flash fire (burning vapour cloud, subsonic flame front)
Explosion Major Occurences: VCE (vapour cloud explosion; supersonic wave front)
Substance Classification: P5b. FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS  cat. 2 or 3  creating hazard conditions (n. 12)
Causes of the accident: Infiltration of vegetable residues into the evaporator.Insufficient maintenance of the evaporator.Failure to detect temperature rise in the evaporator. ;Failure to remove the fan (which creates a vacuum in the extractor) when a problem is detected. ;
Lesson Learned: A comprehensive HAZOP study would be conducted before the unit come into service. ;
